newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Ecuador slaps ban on U.S. oil firm.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador slaps ban on U.S. oil firm.

text.p: Ecuador's populist new government banned a U.S. firm from drilling for oil Wednesday, sent the army to guard its installations and said it would revise all foreign crude oil operations in the country.

President Abdala Bucaram, who was elected in July and calls himself the "president of the poor," ordered a ban on Maxus Energy Corp., owned by Argentine oil giant YPF SA, until it agreed to joint ventures with the state oil firm.
"By order of the President of the Republic and by my order Maxus will not extract another barrel of oil from Ecuadoran soil," said Energy and Mining Minister Alfredo Adoum.
"Either Maxus signs a joint-venture contract or it just leaves the country. I have even issued orders for the armed forces to take possession of the oil fields Maxus is exploiting," he said.
However in Buenos Aires, Nells Leon, president of Maxus' owner YPF, said its oil installations in Ecuador were operating normally and had not been taken by the army.
But he said he expected talks with the government in Quito on the ban would "not be short".
U.S. oil companies with interests in Ecuador privately expressed concern about the implications of developments in the South American nation in the past two days.

"It makes us feel very uncomfortable," said an executive at a U.S. oil company with interests in Ecuador. "It's very confused and there are just too many things going on there a week and a half after they've had a change of government."

The head of state oil company Petroecuador, Patricio Lopez, said the government would revise all contracts with foreign companies extracting crude from Ecuadoran soil "so that each one becomes a benefit for the state."
"Each company is a separate problem and we have to revise each one of them," said Lopez.
Foreign oil firms operating in Ecuador include France's Elf Aquitaine, Spain's Repsol, and Arco and Occidental Petroleum Corp. of the United States.
Maxus is the only one which does not have a production-sharing deal with the government under a regulation requiring that foreign firms grant the state at least 12.5 percent of output.

Lopez assured the ban on Maxus, which has been operating in the Amazon near the Colombian border for nine years, would not affect foreign oil investments: "No way -- as long as companies hand over to the Ecuadoran state a stake, since it is owner of the land and soil and has to have some benefit."

Ecuador accused Maxus of giving "1,000 excuses" to delay signing a new contract and Adoum proclaimed, "We are not going to let them rob us. Up to now, the Ecuadoran people has not had a taste of one single liter of oil extracted by Maxus."
The union representing Petroecuador workers supported the ban on Maxus, which it accused of "yielding the state zero profitability." It called for more foreign oil firm bans.
